document.docAuthor: Orr, Michael C., Pitts, James P. & Griswold, Terry
document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the bee group Anthophora (Micranthophora) (Hymenoptera: Apidae), with notes on potential conservation concerns and a molecular phylogeny of the genus

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Anthophora curta Provancher, 1895: 173
( lectotype ( Sheffield & Perron, 2013 ): ♀ , Los Angeles, California , USA ; coll. Coquillett; ULQC, BBSLID93205).

Anthophora ( Micranthophora ) curta var. melanops Cockerell, 1926: 84
( holotype : ♂ , two miles east of Oracle, Arizona , USA ; coll. E.P. Van Duzee, 24 Jul. 1924 ; CASENT, type 2390). Syn.
Orr et al ., 2014
.

Anthophora ( Micranthophora ) curta var. ensenadensis Cockerell, 1941: 349
( holotype : ♂ , Ensenada, Baja California , Mexico ; coll. W.P. Cockerell, 15 Apr. 1941 ; CASENT, type 15466). Syn. Michener, 1951 .

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. See Fig. 12 . Present in USA : California , Arizona , Nevada , New Mexico , Nevada , Texas , Utah , Oregon , Washington , possibly Oklahoma , possibly Colorado ; Mexico : Baja California Norte, Chihuahua , Baja California Sur , Sonora , Coahuila , Sinaloa , Nuevo Leon , likely Zacatecas , likely San Luis Potosi , possibly Tamaulipas ; possibly Canada : possibly British Columbia . Found in quite varied habitats, though primarily in low to mid-elevation, xeric areas. Ecoregional habitance is as follows, based on 2498 specimen records: 33 ecoregions total: Chihuahuan Desert (863=34.5%), Sonoran Desert (390=15.6%), California coastal sage and chaparral (376=15%), Colorado Plateau shrublands (167=6.7%), California Central Valley grasslands (154=6.2%), Mojave Desert (153=6.1%), California interior chaparral and woodlands (61=2.4%), Arizona Mountains forests (51=2%), California montane chaparral and woodlands (44=1.8%), Sierra de la Laguna dry forests (36=1.4%), Baja California desert (34=1.4%), Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests (22≤1%), Sierra Nevada forests (19≤1%), Snake-Columbia shrub steppe (19≤1%), Klamath-Siskiyou forests (19≤1%), Gulf of California xeric scrub (15≤1%), San Lucan xeric scrub (11≤1%), Great Basin shrub steppe (8≤1%), Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests (8≤1%), Western short grasslands (8≤1%), Northern Mesoamerican Pacific mangroves (7≤1%), NULL (7≤1%), Colorado Rockies forests (5≤1%), Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest (4≤1%), Sinaloan dry forests (3≤1%), Texas blackland prairies (3≤1%), Sierra Juarez and San Pedro Martir pine-oak forest (2≤1%), Meseta Central matorral (2≤1%), Northern California coastal forests (2≤1%), East Central Texas forests (1≤1%), Sierra de la Laguna pine-oak forests (1≤1%), Tamaulipan mezquital (1≤1%), Willamette Valley forests (1≤1%).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 12. Distribution of
Anthophora curta
. Generated with 2498 specimen records from 932 locations.

subSubSection.paragraph: Phenology. Recorded from January–November, primarily spring and fall, heavily dependent on regional rainfall patterns. Likely bivoltine in most areas.

Nesting biology.
Anthophora curta
uses a wide variety of substrates. Hicks (1934) first described this species’ nests in desert pavement in a wide wash. Two new records include the use of hard-packed silt and loose, very dry soil. Further details on these new records will be presented in a subsequent review of the group’s nesting biology.

Floral specialization. Reported as a specialist on
Asteraceae ( Moldenke & Neff 1974 )
. Appears true, and with great breadth, likely enabling its large distribution. Primary recorded visits by 322 females include: Family Asteraceae (81%); Genus
Baileya
(16%); Species
Baileya multiradiata
(12%). 651 total floral records from 24 families include:

Comments.
Anthophora curta
, which was previously synonymized with
A. sqummulosa ( Brooks 1988 )
, was recently restored to specific status (
Orr et al . 2014
).
